channel.title: Arts and Humanities News@Emory
channel.description: All the latest news from Emory University.

item.title: Poet D.A. Powell Places His Papers with Emory
item.description: Award-winning poet D.A. Powell is placing his papers with the Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library (MARBL) at Emory University.

item.title: John Grade to Build Biodegradable Sculptures in Atlanta
item.description: Environmental artist John Grade comes to Atlanta as an Emory University artist-in-residence Nov. 6-19 to design and build large-scale sculptural installations using biodegradable materials.

item.title: 'Accidental Slaveowner' Has Roots in Oxford, Grounded in MARBL Research
item.description: Mark Auslander's story of Miss Kitty, an enslaved woman, and her connection to Emory is the subject of several events.

item.title: 'Accidental Slaveowner' Author to Give Reading at Emory Oct. 24
item.description: Author Mark Auslander will hold a public reading and book signing next week at Emory University to discuss his new release, "The Accidental Slaveowner: Revisiting a Myth of Race and Finding an American Family."

item.title: A Few Things You May Not Know About Water
item.description: Dive in to a "scientific experiment" this weekend through a special interactive dance performance of "Water Study," which will take the audience on a journey through the environment of the Baker Woodlands ravine on campus.

item.title: PODCAST: A Soldier Betrayed in Cuba's Struggle for Freedom
item.description: Emory English and African American Studies professor Mark Sanders edited and translated Afro-Cuban war veteran Ricardo Batrell's autobiography.

item.title: October Music Opens Series, Closes With Two Halloween Favorites
item.description: Jazz on the Green, Liszt bicentennial series and Halloween concerts are this month's music highlights.

item.title: A Geologist Paints Darwin
item.description: Emory geologist Woody Hickcox paints a mural of Charles Darwin during a night at the Fernbank Museum of Natural History. The mural is part of an exhibit of art inspired by evolution, in celebration of the museum's special Darwin exhibit.

item.title: Pick Up a Pencil for the Big Draw Oct. 5
item.description: For the second year, Emory students, staff and faculty will dedicate a day to drawing across campus.

item.title: Beckett Letters Second Volume Debuts in America at Emory
item.description: The American release of "The Letters of Samuel Beckett, Volume 2: 1941-1956" will be celebrated Friday, Oct. 21 at Emory University with readings from Beckett's works and letters by noted Irish actor Barry McGovern, and Atlanta actors Carolyn Cook, Brenda Bynum and Robert Shaw-Smith.

item.title: Fossil Hunter Mary Anning Inspires Art
item.description: Fiber artist Robey Tapp, who also serves as a docent at the Carlos Museum, created a piece inspired by Mary Anning, a self-taught paleontologist and fossil hunter who made important discoveries along England's Jurassic Coast. The art is part of the special Darwin exhibit at the Fernbank Museum.

item.title: Emory Alumnus Wins MacArthur Fellowship
item.description: Tiya Miles, who received her master's degree in Women's Studies from Emory University in 1995, has been named one of 22 new MacArthur Fellows for 2011.

item.title: Atlanta Music Festival Sept. 21-24 to Feature Opera Singer Indra Thomas
item.description: Emory University, Atlanta's First Congregational Church and Meridian Herald present the 2011 Atlanta Music Festival: Songs of Aspiration, Hope and Progress Sept. 21-24. The festival will feature performances by international opera star and Atlanta native Indra Thomas and a dramatic re-creation of the inaugural performance of James Weldon JohnsonÂ¿s "Lift Every Voice and Sing."

item.title: Soiree Spotlights Arts Season, Community Artists
item.description: A swirl of music, dance, poetry reading and visual arts exhibits offered a kaleidoscopic look at this year's arts scene at Emory.

item.title: Exhibition Sheds Light on Expatriates in Paris
item.description: Paris of the 1920s is the focus of a new exhibition "Shadows of the Sun: The Crosbys, the Black Sun Press and the Lost Generation," on display now in the Schatten Gallery at Emory University's Woodruff Library.
